title: The Rise of Systems Thinking
introduction: Using Web of Life Ch. 2 - Capra (1996)

2.Title: Cartesian Mechanics
2.Description: Mechanism is the belief that natural wholes (principally living things) are like complicated machines or artifacts, composed of parts lacking any intrinsic relationship to each other. Thus, the source of an apparent thing's activities is not the whole itself, but its parts or an external influence on the parts.

8.Title: Aristotles theories on matter
8.Description: The first biologist in Western tradition, Aristotle believed substance and form were linked. He created a formal system of logic and a set of unifying concepts for the main disciplines of his time-- biology, physics, metaphysics, ethics, and politics.

9.Title: Galileos discoveries
9.Description: Galileo studies phenomena that can be measured and quantified. The view of the world as a machine begins to emerge

10.Title: Descartes formalizes analytic thinking
10.Description: Rene Descartes method consists of breaking up complex phenomena into pieces to understand the behavior of the whole from the properties of its parts. Seperates all things into the realms of 'mind' and 'matter' and says that exact mathematical laws govern all matter. William Harvey successfully applies Descartes' mechanistic model to the phenomenom of blood circulation.

11.Title: Newtonian Mechanics
11.Description: Isaac Newton's laws of motion are published in 1687. Newton believes these laws can be used to explain all physical systems.

12.Title: Goethe sees patterns within patterns
12.Description: Goethe uses the term "morphology" to describe the study of biological form from a dynamic, developmental point of view. Argues that must be seen as a whole

13.Title: Immanuel Kant and the start of the Romantic Movement
13.Description: Believed that science could only offer a mechanical view of the world. He proposed there was need to consider the idea that nature is purposeful. Seeds of the modern day Gaia Hypothesis are found here.

14.Title: James Hutton
14.Description: Maintained that geological and biological processes are all interlinked; compared the Earths waters to a circulatory system.

15.Title: Alexander Von Humboldt
15.Description: Has a habit of "viewing earth as a great whole". Humboldt identifies climate as a unifying global force and recognizes the coevolution of living organisms, climate, and the Earth crust. The almost entirely encapsulates the contemporary Gaia hypothesis.

16.Title: George Cuvier creates zoological classification
16.Description: based on similiaraties of forms, not chemical composition

17.Title: The rise of the Light Microscope swings the pendulum back towards mechanistic thought
17.Description:
The performance of a light microscope depends on the quality and correct use of the condensor lens system to focus light on the specimen and the objective lens to capture the light from the specimen and form an image.[5] Early instruments were limited until this principle was fully appreciated and developed from the late 19th to very early 20th century, and until electric lamps were available as light sources. In 1893 August Köhler developed a key principle of sample illumination, Köhler illumination, which is central to achieving the theoretical limits of resolution for the light microscope.

The ability to study materials at microscopic levels leads to a flurry of advances in biology.

18.Title: Rudolf Virchow formulates modern cell theory
18.Description: The focus of biology shifts from life forms (organisms) to life parts (cells). Biological functions are now once again seen as the results of interactions among cellular building blocks.

19.Title: Louis Pastuer
19.Description: Dominates the new field of microbiology. Is able to establish the role of bacteria is certain chemical processes. Demonstartes a clear correlation between "germs" (microorganisms) and disease.

20.Title: Jacques Loeb's 'The Mechanistic Conception of Life'
20.Description: Summarized the new belief among biologists that all properties and functions of living organisms would eventually be explained in terms of chemical and physical laws.

21.Title: Vitalism Phase
21.Description:
The process of an organism developing still could not be explained by the mechanistic view of life. This lead to Vitalism as an alternative.

Vitalists believed that although the laws of physics and chemistry are applicable to organisms, they are insufficient to fully understand the phenonmenon of life. 
In short, the whole is more than the sum of its parts.

However, Vitalists believed specifically that a non-physical entity, force, or field must be added to the laws of physics and chemistry to understand life. This belief was soon challenged by Organismic theory.

22.Title: Hans Driesch's sea urchin egg experiments
22.Description:
Driesch observed that when he destroyed one of the cells of the embryo at the very early two-celled stage, the remaining cell developed into not half an urchin, but into a complete but smaller organism. The eggs had done what a machine could never do: they had regenerated wholes from parts. 

There is evidence that Driesch looked strenuously for a missing pattern of organization. Rather than turning to the concept of pattern, he postulated a causal factor: a seperate entity working on the organism without being part of it.

23.Title: The rise of Organism Biology
23.Description: Opposing both mechanism and vitalism, organismic biologists took up the problem of biological form with new enthusiam. Key insights of Aristotle, Goethe, Kant and Cuvier were elaborated upon and refined.

24.Title: Ross Harrison
24.Description: explored the concept of organization, which had gradually come to replace function in physiology. Harrison identified configuration and relationship as two important aspects of organization, which were subsequently unified in the concept of pattern as a configuration of ordered relationships.

25.Title: Lawrence Henderson's systems
25.Description: Early use of the term 'system' to describe living organisms and social systems. Over time, "systems thinking" comes to mean the understanding of a phenomenon within the context of a larger whole.

26.Title: Quantum Physics
26.Description:
Since Newton, Physicists had believed that all physical phenomenom could be reduced to the properties of hard and solid material particles. Quantum theory forced them to accept that the solid material objects of classical physics dissolve at the subatomic level into wavelike patterns of probabilties. 
Moreover, these patterns do not represent probabilities of things, but rather probabilities of interconnections.

27.Title: "Emergent Properties"
27.Description:
C. D. Broad coins the term "Emergent Properities" to describe those properties that emerge at a certain level of complexity but do not exist at lower levels. 
For example, the concept of temperature, which is central to thermodynamics, is meaningless at the level of individual atoms.
Similiarly, the taste of sugar is not present in the carbon, oxygen, and hydrogen atoms that constitute its components.

28.Title: Biological Principals marks the end of the debate between mechanists and vitalists
28.Description:
Joseph Needham maintained the publication 'Biological Principals'. Needham's early work was on the problems in the biochemistry of development. He was always interested in the philosophical and historical dimensions of science and wrote many essays in defense of the mechanistic paradigm but subsequently came to embrace the organismic outlook.
"A logical analysis of the concept of organism, leads us to look for organizing relations at all levels, higher and lower, coarse and fine, of the living structure."

29.Title: Systems Thinking
29.Description:
According to the systems view, the essential properties of an organism, or living system, are properties of the whole - which none of the parts have. They arise from the interactions and  relationships among the parts. This was a great shock to twentieth century science that systems cannot be understood by reductionist analysis. The properties of the parts are not intrinsic properties but can be understood only within the context of the larger whole. 
Thus, the relationships between parts and whole has been reversed within Western Science. In the systems approach the properties of the parts can only be understood from the organization of the whole.
